para.paratext: Under O.C.G.A. § 24-7-701(b), an expert or lay witness may give opinion evidence regarding market value of an item or property if he has had an opportunity to form a reasoned opinion about it. A lay witness does not have to be skilled in the area of valuation, but must be better able to form an opinion regarding the value of property or services at issue, through observation or personal knowledge, than people in general.[1] Daubert standards do not apply to market value opinions.[2]

A qualified witness may base his opinion on hearsay,[3] such as knowledge of comparable sales, but cannot prove such sales by his hearsay statement.[4] An expert on real estate value will base his opinion on market data or comparable sales, reproduction or replacement cost less depreciation, or capitalization of income. Testimony of an expert as to value will be excluded, however, if the expert cannot provide the methodology by which he reached his conclusions as to value.[5] Moreover, although a witness may not qualify to give expert testimony as to value, he may give lay testimony to the same fact, provided he had ample opportunity to form a reasoned opinion.[6] A property owner is qualified to state his opinion as to value.[7] Toney v. Johns[8] includes a good discussion of the foundation necessary for a property owner to testify about value of an item (jewelry).

The purchase price of a truck was prima facie evidence of value.[9] In Reeves v. Crawford,[10] the court struck the testimony of an automobile owner who admitted on cross-examination that his opinion regarding the value of his vehicle before and after a collision was “mostly guesswork.”

In Southern Cellular Telecom, Inc. v. Banks,[11] the trial court properly allowed a 49% shareholder to give her opinion of the fair market value of her stock in an action to recover damages arising from the sale of stock back to the parent company.

In Sevostiyanova v. Tempest Recovery Services, Inc.,[12] the testimony of car owner was inadmissible to show the fair market value of a car at the time it was repossessed and sold because she had no education or experience in the valuation of vehicles and presented no evidence of the price she paid for car, the condition of the car at the time it was repossessed, the potential market for such cars at time of repossession, or other relevant factors to be considered in reaching a conclusion about the car's value.

An arson victim who was a real estate investor, repaired houses, and had done contracting work had sufficient knowledge to provide an opinion as to the damages he suffered as result of fire that damaged his home.[13]
Market reports are admissible to prove value of property listed on a general commodity market.[14]
Expert testimony is admissible to prove market value and diminution value of real property and the value of personal property affected in an inverse condemnation case.[15]
Safari v. RES-MS Bayfront, LLC, 333 Ga. App. 164, 775 S.E.2d 637 (2015).
Apostle v. Prince, 158 Ga. App. 56, 279 S.E.2d 304 (1981), held that a non-expert owner could base his opinion on hearsay.

Abernethy v. Cates, 182 Ga. App. 456, 356 S.E.2d 62 (1987), held that the concept of ordinary wear and tear was within the common knowledge of man and it was not necessary for a witness to be an expert to state his opinion.

An appraiser who calculated the market value of real property for purposes of a proceeding to confirm a foreclosure sale could base her estimate of the cost to complete the buildings on the property on a construction cost manual and her own list of unfinished items in the buildings. Even though the appraiser was not a construction expert, the use of an expert is not the only acceptable method for the calculating construction costs. Nash v. Compass Bank, 296 Ga. App. 874, 676 S.E.2d 28 (2009).
See, e.g., Blue Marlin Development, LLC v. Branch Banking & Trust Co., 302 Ga. App. 120, 690 S.E.2d 252 (2010).

Powers v. Powers, 213 Ga. 461, 99 S.E.2d 818 (1957); Garner v. Gwinnett County, 105 Ga. App. 714, 125 S.E.2d 563 (1962); Clemones v. Alabama Power Co., 107 Ga. App. 489, 130 S.E.2d 600 (1963); Haynes v. Huff, 165 Ga. App. 192, 299 S.E.2d 902 (1983).

Although he could base his opinion on hearsay, in Bryant v. General Motors Acceptance Corp., 184 Ga. App. 323, 361 S.E.2d 529, 5 U.C.C. Rep. Serv. 2d 830 (1987), the witness in that case had not had a proper opportunity for forming an opinion.
State Highway Dept. v. Wilkes, 106 Ga. App. 634, 127 S.E.2d 715 (1962) (overruled in part on other grounds by, State Highway Dept. v. Howard, 119 Ga. App. 298, 167 S.E.2d 177 (1969)).
See Merritt v. Department of Transp., 147 Ga. App. 316, 248 S.E.2d 689 (1978), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 243 Ga. 52, 252 S.E.2d 508 (1979), in regard to comparable sales.
Woodrum v. Georgia Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company, 347 Ga. App. 89, 815 S.E.2d 650 (2018).
Woodrum v. Georgia Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company, 347 Ga. App. 89, 815 S.E.2d 650 (2018).
Williams v. State, 246 Ga. App. 347, 540 S.E.2d 305 (2000); Seaboard Coast Line R. Co. v. Toole, 128 Ga. App. 24, 195 S.E.2d 282 (1973).

In Schoolcraft v. DeKalb County, 126 Ga. App. 101, 189 S.E.2d 915 (1972), it was error to exclude the condemnee's opinion as to the value of his property and damages thereto. However, in Department of Transp. v. Kirk, 138 Ga. App. 180, 225 S.E.2d 781 (1976), it was error to permit the owner of property to testify as to the value of the property without showing some basis for the opinion. In Safari v. RES-MS Bayfront, LLC, 333 Ga. App. 164, 775 S.E.2d 637 (2015), the court reversed the grant of summary judgment where the trial court refused to consider the owner's opinion testimony regarding the value of his land.
Toney v. Johns, 153 Ga. App. 880, 267 S.E.2d 298 (1980).

Sentry Ins. v. Henderson, 138 Ga. App. 495, 226 S.E.2d 759 (1976). Godowns v. Cantrell, 186 Ga. App. 100, 366 S.E.2d 415 (1988), contains a good discussion of testimony as to market value of an automobile.
Reeves v. Crawford, 185 Ga. App. 518, 364 S.E.2d 895 (1988).
Southern Cellular Telecom, Inc. v. Banks, 208 Ga. App. 286, 431 S.E.2d 115, 118 (1993).
Sevostiyanova v. Tempest Recovery Services, Inc., 307 Ga. App. 868, 705 S.E.2d 878 (2011).
Mayfield v. State, 307 Ga. App. 630, 705 S.E.2d 717 (2011).
Pribeagu v. Gwinnett County, 336 Ga. App. 753, 785 S.E.2d 567 (2016).
